newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Strike hits Morocco's Cosumar sugar plant.
newsitem.headline: Strike hits Morocco's Cosumar sugar plant.

text.p: Morocco's main sugar refiner Cosumar was paralysed on Wednesday with workers on an indefinite strike, a union spokesman said.

"The management's irrational behaviour and provocation pushed Cosumar workers to an indefinite strike...The (Casablanca-based) refinery was paralysed on Wednesday...as no solution was found yet to the dispute," Fouad Benseddik, Union Marocaine du Travail (Moroccan Work Union - UMT) spokesman, told Reuters by telephone.
He said the strike had started last week.
The dispute involved pay rises for the workforce and compensation for workers laid off as part of the restructuring being carried out by the firm, he said.
Cosumar, a subsidiary of Morocco's largest conglomerate ONA group, has nearly 3,000 employees and annual production of 670,000 tonnes of sugar.
An ONA manager said that the firm had given all due rights for the workers.

"Compensations and other benefits have been paid to the workers...The refinery is undergoing a restructuring policy...and it is in the interest of everybody to comply with this policy to face forthcoming foreign competitiveness," the manager said.

"We are aware of the firm's restructuring policy, we agree with it but we cannot accept the immediate layoff of 350 workers, including 40 UMT affiliates," Benseddik said, adding that the problem could be resolved through serious dialogue.
According to Cosumar officials the refinery had enough refined sugar stock to respond to the market's immediate demands.
Cosumar, which is the country's major importer and refiner of raw sugar, bought more than half a million tonnes of raw sugar or about 50 percent of Moroccan consumption in 1996.
On the Casablanca bourse, Cosumar was last traded at 880 dirhams per share.
